awd_titl_txt: The Science and Fundamental Understanding of the Radio Frequency Surface Resistance of Nitrogen Doped SRF cavities
awd_abstract_narration:
The research enabled by this award will improve the understanding of one of the physical processes that determine, and may ultimately limit, the performance of future particle accelerators.  Particle accelerators have a wide variety of uses, from basic research machines for fundamental studies of elementary particle physics to tools and instruments ranging from industrial welding to medical diagnostics and treatment.  One of the key limiting factors for particle accelerators can be the performance of superconducting, radio-frequency cavities that are used to accelerate the electrically charged particles. By discovering the mechanisms presently contributing to energy dissipation within such cavities, we can push the technology to theoretical limits for the next generation of superconducting particle accelerators. This research project involves the training of graduate students as the next generation of research leaders with expertise in accelerator science and technology, as well as the physics of superconducting materials for particle accelerators and related technologies.

This award supports research and graduate education in the field of superconducting, radio-frequency (RF) accelerator science. The research supported by this award is directed towards a fundamental understanding of the physical processes governing the region of field penetration into Nitrogen-doped Niobium superconductors used in state-of-the-art RF cavities for particle accelerators. The research involves physical and chemical characterization, on the sub-nanometer scale, of the sub-micron deep surface layer near the vacuum-superconducting interface where the RF screening currents flow. Surface profile characterization, from sub-nano-meter to micron length scales, will be carried out, and combined with local electronic and magnetic properties obtained from atom-probe reconstruction, nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy, and transport measurements in the normal metallic phase of Niobium. The detailed atomic-scale structure of the surface and screening region will be combined with state-of-the-art theoretical modeling and computational theory for the RF currents under high-field conditions. The overarching goal is to push performance of next-generation superconducting RF cavities to theoretical limits.

por.por_cntn:
This project covers theoretical and experimental research aimed at developing a fundamental understanding of the physical processes and material properties that determine the ultimate limits to the performance of Superconducting Radio Frequency (SRF) cavities for particle accelerators. The focus is on the physical processes and materials properties that limit two key figures of merit for the operational performance of SRF cavities for high-energy physics accelerator technology: (i) the quality factor Q which measures the efficiency of the cavity in confining the electromagnetic field within the vacuum region in which the field accelerates charged particles, and (ii) the maximum accelerating field, Emax , that defines how effective the SRF cavities are in accelerating charged particles to very high energies. A third parameter, , is the shift in the cavity resonance frequency when the cavity becomes superconducting.

The key outcomes of this project are highlighted in the points below.

  • Based on first-principles theory of superconductivity under accelerator conditions the project developed pathways to increase the maximum accelerating field for Nb-based SRF cavities by engineering the impurity distribution profile near the vacuum-superconducting interface. Accelerating fields approaching 60 MV/m are predicted to be achievable as the new theoretical limit.
  • Experiments carried out at Fermilab revealed negative frequency shifts of the cavity resonance of order kHz in a narrow temperature range () near the superconducting transition for Nitrogen doped Niobium SRF cavities with fundamental frequencies ranging from 0.65 ? 2.6 GHz, and quality factors approaching 1011 that are sensitive to the surface preparation. First principles theory for the a.c. current response led to accurate prediction of these current anomalies, providing a powerful analysis tool for the level of disorder and quality of the cavity.
  • The project opened new training and educational opportunities for students in physics, applied physics and materials science by combining the academic structure of the graduate program in Applied Physics at Northwestern with the Center for Applied Physics and Superconducting Technologies that is a joint center between Northwestern?s Office of Research and Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory.

This project involved 3 PhD students, two post-doctoral fellows, the PI (Northwestern) and co-Pis (Fermilab). Graduate students receive advanced training in analytical and computational methods, and multiple approaches to problem solving, which can be used in a broad range of endeavors in science and engineering.
